This is a review after finishing s2. The first half of s1 and the second half of the s2 were the most enjoyable part for me, from episodes 7 - 18 the show was painful. One of the things that I liked is the end, it felt really closed and satisfying. 6 is good, not bad, I kinda liked the show. 
Characters: ok character development for the most part, Ito and Ayado felt like the weaker characters in the show. Most of the cast is or becomes pretty likeable.
Sound: OST is OK, VA too.
Art: kinda cute, not bad but it's like... too bright.
Animation: A disaster,especially after the first half of s1, it doesn't get better than that. Really clunky, lazy and funny.\n\n
Story: a romantic drama, simple as that. The side characters get a lot of attention and that is something that I enjoyed.\n\n
Mayor issue: the drama feels too forced and repetitive sometimes, especially in the episodes that I listed as painful. Ito and Ayado were annoying for me. The MC and everything Otaku related feels too exaggerated. At least the MC improves and starts to act like a person.\n\n
Overrall: cute romantic drama with some comedy here and there that doesn't do that much, it has an ending. If you want some romance or drama then you could watch it, but there are some better shows out there.

So from what i have been seeing from other reviews people really didn't like this anime at all. I was wondering why that was so i decided to give it a watch and then see what i thought in the end. After watching this season of the show i can say that i actually like this anime. Not a lot but i did like it. I find the romance very nice and seeing the progress of the main characters change was also very nice. Seeing Iroha Igarashi go from this person that is a social outcast, doesn't like real girls, and likes to watch animewith his best friend Yūto Itō. To become this person that wants to make his relationship with Hikari Tsutsui actually work. 


First what i thought about the story. I think the story was really good. I felt really close to Iroha because the people around me don't understand the reason why i like anime in the first place. Then when i try and explain it i get made fun of for it. So i understood what Iroha was going through. On top of that this anime had great character building moments not just with Iroha, but with all of the main and side characters you see through out the show. Most of the time you only see the change of only the main characters, but with this show you see all of the characters change in some way shape or form and that is what i really like about the story. There were times were i thought the story didn't make sense or didn't really need to be there, but all in all i really did like this story.


Next the art. The art used for some of the scenes were very interesting when a romantic moment was happening. I liked when the background would change to this different art style to show how important the moment. It give meaning to the characters romantic relationship and not something you want to ignore. When i see an anime to something different with its art style instead of sticking to the same backgrounds and same colors i cant help but enjoy that anime even more just because they do something different with the art. 


Now the sound. The sound effects for the anime were pretty good. Nothing really popes up as exciting to me, but that's only through the sound effects. The music is something else though. When the mood changes or a character is thinking about something the music helps with this to make the viewer understand what the characters are going through. In real life when you think you always have a song in the back of your mind that plays when you want to think very long over something. This is what this anime does with the actually characters. They set the music to be emotionally to the character or characters depending on the scene and that's something i also like about anime. 


Now lets talk about the characters. I have already talked a little bit about them in the beginning of this review, but there are a few more things i would say about them. Overall each character has a unique personality to them and when they all meet with each other it feels like the real them is coming out. An example would be for Iroha. Iroha wants to be by himself and think that whatever he does or what other do to him doesn't change him. But after meeting Hikari he starts to change his personality when around her and his friends. Each character has this kind of moment to realize that maybe what they have been doing wasn't the right think and by the end of the first season they realized that Iroha isn't that awkward or strange as they first thought he was. They got to know him and change there thoughts about him. Something that most people to try and do in real life today. 


Finally my overall enjoyment for the anime. I thoroughly enjoyed watching this anime because i felt like Iroha at points. I knew what he was feeling because i have been in the same spot as him. I have changed from others just as the same as him. And i have not been as bad at talking to others as i was a few years ago. I feel connected with this character and when that happens i just really like an anime just a little more then i thought i was going to like it.


Overall this anime is not as bad as people make it out to be. You just need to give it a chance and not compare it to other shows of the same nature. Because not all anime are the same and i can safely say that i will be watching the second season of this just so i can see the connection between the characters even more.

Think about shit, now think about this anime. You know what's similar? Humans shit out shit. 
The first 6 episodes of this anime is bearable, but the animations, characters, story, and everything starts to become a used diaper. I can't say anything unique about this anime. I was annoyed by two characters, Ito and Ayodo, I couldn't stand the laziness the anime tries to attempt with its animations, and the characters that were introduced is like any other anime I have ever watched.
The difference of the anime is the plot. The main character started a relationship with this girl, but she is moving out inthe next 6 months, so the main character tries to spend as much time as possible with her. That itself is fine, but nothing is built on it. The first 6 episodes are the only good episodes I would at least say. It's a 3/10 there, but the rest just painfully worn me out.\n\n
Don't watch this anime, unless you want to admire the laziness this anime has to offer.

I feel 3D Kanojo gets a lot of bad rep just from the fact that it is getting a second season while many popular franchises remain in limbo. If you can put aside resentment or comparison, what you will find is a pretty decent little romance with enough heartfelt moments to carry an otherwise banal production.
EYES - F
Visually the show looks just plain bad. The character designs range from great (Iroha) to barely tolerable (basically the rest of the cast except Ishino), the art is generic and blah, and the animation is comically awful. The direction is there but it adds little to the toneor the story that the manga didn't already have. If you can laugh at the animation and get sucked into the main romance at the same time, you will enjoy this show.


EARS - C


Nothing of note to report here. The sound effects are generic but not overbearing, and the OP and ED are catchy but nothing special. The voice acting stands out, with solid performances from Serizawa Yuu as Iroha and Tsuda Minami as Ishino. The soundtrack does what most soundtracks do nowadays - blend in - and it for the most part makes no impact. Every now and then you'll notice a catchy riff in there somewhere, but it almost never adds much to the experience of watching the show.


HEART - B-


This is what carries 3D Kanojo. The writing isn't anything spectacular or groundbreaking, but the romance between Tsutsui and Iroha is incredibly real and solidly carried out. The finale is as heartwarming as the whole romance is throughout, and watching the two grow together through is charming to say the least. Tsutsui is fairly generic conceptually, but his psyche is explored in a surprisingly interesting way, and while he comes out slightly above average he does enough work as a character to make the romance what it is. Igarashi Iroha is a real joy to watch, and she's the most interesting character in the whole show with her promiscuous backstory and emotional arc. While 3D Kanojo explores more of the supporting cast and side characters than I would like, it's more that I wish the side characters were better and less that I disliked their episodes. Ishino - my spirit animal - is an absolute revelation, but Takanashi, Ito, Ayado, Anzu, Kaoru, ototo, and the rest of the cast are all pretty mediocre. Except for the mom, she's a ballerr.  


There aren't any big overarching themes to speak of - which is probably my favorite part about the show. It delves into specific, real situations and emotions the main couple feels, and just kind of explores whatever it wants to. But it does so pretty damn well, and it was an especially thought-provoking experience given some recent stuff in my personal life.



OVERALL - C+


3D Kanojo is not going to knock your socks off or blow you out of the water. In the romance category it doesn't even stand up to the likes of Kare Kano, or Monogatari, or Doukyuusei, or Tsurezure Children, or Cardcaptor Sakura - but it doesn't need to. Those are all great shows in their own right, but while what 3D Kanojo brings to the table is not dissimilar to what other titles offer, it is indeed a unique flavor in its own way. Again, if you can laugh at the atrocious animation and get hooked by the main couple and/or Ishino, you will enjoy this show as I did. Just don't go in comparing it to the classics.

What a frustratingly terrible experience. This was on of the worst high school romances I’ve ever seen. It manages to take every single cliche and amplify it to annoying levels. It takes the worst parts of every high school romance, adds in subpar animation and art style, forgettable music, bland and annoying characters, and some outright cringeworthy lines of dialogue. While the first 2 or 3 episodes were a mix of fun to laugh at scenes and scenes of second hand embarrassment, those were the best episodes in the series. It got worse and worse as it went on. 3D Kanojo has some of theworst drama situations I’ve ever seen in anime period. They make no sense, all the character overreact like crazy, and it just made me want to see the main couple break up. For me, a romance anime has failed when I actively WANT the main couple to break up. The fights they got in were dumb and could’ve been easily avoided and solved, they were shown countless times why it shouldn’t work out between them, and it just became a pain to root for them to stay together. On the bright side, at least the moments of calm were entertaining to laugh at due to how dumb the dialogue was. The moments of calm were almost always immediately followed by more instances of drama however. It got frustrating and very old very quickly. The characters were all terrible. Some of their personalities seemed to change on the spot just to fan the flames of drama even more. 3D Kanojo was nothing more than Otaku bait so fans could go “Hey, this MC is an Otaku like me! I relate to him and this anime is so good now because this is basically me!” while completely ignoring the terrible plot lines, god awful characters, laughable dialogue, and the bad animation. Somehow, this is getting a 2nd Season in 2019. I can’t wait for 12 more episodes of miscommunications, misunderstandings, terrible characters, and more laughable dialogue. This was without a single doubt, the worst anime of the season and a strong contender for worst anime of the year.

Of all the shows this season, real girl has got to be one of the most disappointing. I did not exactly have high expectations of this show initially thinking it was just going to be a poor quality wish fulfilment anime. My expectations were not exceeded.
In terms of story it was an incredibly basic plot. Otaku meets pretty girl, pretty girl falls in love with said otaku ect.  Whilst it was not awful it was neither great or original. I can't say much more as there isn't a lot to say about it. 5/10
The Characters are also a little cliché and although in thefirst couple of episodes I found them likable, i grew to find most of the characters (especially the mc) irritating and dull. There are a few characters i enjoyed throughout but that number is very limited. 6/10\n\n
The animation from hoods was fine at best with no stand out moments in terms of art direction or animation as a whole. 5/10\n\n
Overall i would not recommend this series but it was not entirely awful. It's only real redeeming feature was the sound design which i thought was quite well done but the rest of the series was mediocre at best, getting worse as the show continued. The only real reason i watched it all was because i hate to drop something once I've watched a fair amount of it.\n
5/10

STORY
-Event the idea was quite intriguing and this anime was one of the first to add as plan to watch, it disappointed me in so many ways.
CHARACTERS
-The main character - Tsutsun - was completely uninteresting, and even if he was kind-hearted, he had no special traits at all. Otakus are not that plain. Just look how famous WOTAKOI became because it shows the bad and the good, the true behind loving anime stuff how we got related to that!
-The girl. There is a good side and a bad side of course. The good one: She had superficial relationships all this time for some good reasons,to feel her empty heart, and she wanted to give a chance to a different type of a guy. Although she had the expectation of him to treat her like he had a tone of relationships before and made him so miserable and he lost the tiny confidence he had. I didn't like the guy, but that was really shitty of her and made me feel annoyed of her. Also, she knew she would go away in 6 months, but for her own good she was ok with putting this boy in all this trouble, falling in love with her and then break his heart when she would go away. She took advantage of him. \n\n
ART?SOUND\n
- worse than mediocre, plain, it was clear the animation company didn't try much for this project

I didn't care for the summary and plot of this anime but it was romance so I decided to give it a try. Didn't work out and I'm not surprised. The site I was watching this on each week always seemed to have an issue and I didn't care enough for this anime to look around for another site to watch this on, add in MAL not being open for me to update my progress, I just took it as a sign to stop torturing myself with this.
It's just an over the top angsty teen romance about a social outcast who gets bullied finally gettinga girlfriend and thus starts becoming friends with other people. But I guess the twist was that this chick was supposed to be leaving in six months. She didn't want to deal with friends because of her short time at the school, but wanted to have a boyfriend? Yeah, that's logical.


That short time and she spends most of the time being a moody female dog over nothing half the time. And then another female chick he befriends always sides with this moody chick because apparently, her sour mood is always all his fault. And despite them being in high school, she resorts to grade school antics and lacks any kind of real communication skills to talk to him about anything.


I stopped watching the episode after the camp trip where they came back. Another girl admitted to the girlfriend that she likes her boyfriend and the girlfriend is mad at the boyfriend because he's nice and thus he made her fall in love with him. So they get back to school and she still avoids him.


I can't do it anymore. I'm sick of this overly dramatic teen school mess. Why can't they come out with anime mature anime like Nana? Ugh!

This show is one of those anime you just want to watch when you sit down and relax. It is not a show that will be on your favorites list by any means, but it does its job I guess.
Story: Nerding guy starts dating the most beautiful girl in the school and is constantly doubting himself
Art and Sound: I thought the art was alright, nothing special in the backgrounds, but the character designs were nice. I really liked the voice actors, especially for the main female character, just something about her voice made me smile. Best friend's voice sucked though.
Character: I will say that Idid not have the highest of expectations for this show, but the main character is a pushover that is constantly doubting himself then has moments of "grow the hell up." I absolutely despise the best friend in this show. Probably one of the worst "best friends" in recent anime. The female lead and the other side characters are not too bad, but dear god, I hated the sections with the best friend and his voice was AWFUL.\n\n
Overall: It is a light-hearted anime that has its fault, if you hate wimpy main male characters, then this show is not for you. While the "Best friend" is awful, you can bear it for the cute moments throughout each episode. Seriously, you really have to be a big anime fan to find enjoyment out of this.

Real Girl can't be more cliche and stereotypical, but it's where the show really shines, in being cliche and stereotypical. Beware of some spoilers.
Story (8/10):
Hikaru Tsutsui is your typical otaku who watches anime for long hours and is a big fan of Ezomichi (a magical girl anime) who even talks with her, but this changes when he meets Iroha Igarashi, a wild beautiful 3D girl who had many relationships with men and somehow got infatuated with Tsutsui. Iroha clearly mentions that the relationship will only last 6 months as she has to move.
New adventures will come with this eccentric couple, with many difficulties encountering theway and Hikaru trying to understand, not only why Iroha chose him, but how real girls are. This sounds very cliche, but the execution is basically flawless, it doesn't resorts to cheap panty shots, unnatural female proportions and cheap drama, only focuses on the story and the love and drama of the cast.


Art (7/10):

Not great, but not bad, just good. Clearly Hoods Entertainment have to put much more effort after the fallout of Märchen Mädchen, and it clearly paid off here, a better-than-average art and animation which clearly express the true nature of the cast.


Sound (7/10):

A more than acceptable soundtrack and theme songs, which I clearly highlight the ED as the best part of the series, its lyrics are very common, but still powerful and endearing. The character voice acting was mostly on song with the tone of the anime, not quite good, but not bad.


Characters (8/10):

Very cliche characters, you have your typical male otaku MC who somehow get entangled in a relationship with the hottest girl of the school, Tsutsui actually improves along the way, and while having big self-confidence issues, he mostly manages to understand his girlfriend Iroha. Igarashi is a very stereotypical beautiful girl with behaviour problems who falls in love with the otaku Tsutsui, she, like Hikari, has doubts with herself about how his boyfriend operates and if he really cares about her.


Yuuto Itou is very typical of the sidekick of the MC, and as all the cast, he clearly grows in the series, even falling in love. Arisa Ishino is very blunt and sometimes hurtful, but mellows downs while recognizing the reality of her closest confidents. Mitsuya Takanashi is the classical enemy of the MC who opposes the relationships, Sumie Ayado is the stereotypical female otaku who fantasizes with Tsutsui for being considerate towards her.


As you can see, all of the characters are cliche, stereotypes of something, but with this flaw, all of them recognizes their pros and cons and the growth of all the cast makes this a strong point.


Enjoyment (9/10):

A romance anime lover like me will truly appreciate this anime, even taking out the problems of being cliche and stereotypical, you'll find a very interesting anime who shines in actually being stereotypical and the realness of their characters. And with the second season incoming next year, we'll be surely to get the final resolution of this series.


Final Score: 8/10.

While not exactly very good, 3d kanojo real girl can quickly become an induced craving anime, and can affect you in some subtle way. Its constantly changing pace, but doing so with a careful approach that will not get too confusing (quite rare in a romcom), and which reflects the thoughts process of the protagonists.
Midway, it creates an elegant and refined setting to provide a simple but not cheap romance, seemingly without arrogance. Typically the kind of anime that makes you think just when you're about to take a break from it ... 
"come on, just one more episode".
Unfortunately, from all that, this show won'tget exactly any better. For starters, its execution is far from flawless. Take the characters for example : I can understand a romcom don't exactly need outstanding graphics, but you could make sure at the very least that the main female lead could not get confused with her friend (and vice-versa). \n
And it's not stopping at characters drawings clones. The show clearly lacks boldness, quite frankly, from his debut to its ending. Here's another example : being shunned as an otaku, the male main lead is most of the time seen as a gross, ugly boy. But ugly, really ? Is he ? Then why Takanashi is supposed to be a lady killer when his features are not that far from Ito ? To me they all look like pretty people if nothing else. All that to say that the supposed "gap" - be it exterior or interior - between the characters are not that obvious in any way, which in turn makes this anime tropes quite more obvious. Maybe it's not as important a theme as it is in "Ore Monogatari!!" or "Lovely Complex" (both which heavily relies on exterior looks/appearance issues) but since the otaku theme (even if we're not talking about exterior aspects issues here) is reminded all over the show, I was expecting more clashes on this particular subject.\n
Now, provided that you're not expecting too much from the issues forced on the characters and the contrived solutions that emerges from them, 3d kanojo real girl can still be quite enjoyable, sometimes from its soft pace and delicate situations, sometimes from the more serious aspects of life and scenes that follows, along the story. But I honestly still think the title alone is misleading.

Our male protagonist is that stereotypical nerdy otaku boy who is so ugly and socially inept that people feel actively repulsed by him on first sight (they only really start to hate him once they get to know him closer and get more exposure to his shitty personality).
Our female protagonist is that stereotypical hot and "popular-but-strangely-aloof" girl all the hot and popular boys want, but who hasn't got any female friends for some inscrutable reason that defies logic. She dates around a lot, but all those hot and popular boys can't satisfy her deeply felt need for otaku D so she must keep looking -she's like a princess who keeps kissing princes in the hope one of them will turn into a frog. 


The two meet, and romantic sparks immediately fly, because this is a romcom with nerdy otakus as the target group, and extensive focus group testing showed that they wanted the otaku to get the girl right off the bat, so there's not a second to lose.


And so the girl instantly falls for the boy, who hates her guts at first since he basically hates all people, and especially those who are happier than him (which is basically all people), but she keeps kissing him out of the blue and trying to bang him until he reluctantly falls for her in return. 


There's not much relationship realism to be found in this "romcom", but at least *that* part is pretty spot on! Any girl who reads this who don't know how to convince a boy to fall for her should follow the example set here and just keep throwing herself at the boy until she sticks, boys can't really defend against that deviously cunning strategy in the long run!


But I digress. The point I'm trying to make here is just that the only reason these two character ends up in a relationship is because it says so in the script, so they don't really have a choice. The romance is CONTRIVED.


The nerdy otaku boy has no clue what the popular hot girl sees in him, but more importantly, neither has the viewer. As usual in this kind of otaku-pandering animes, it is explained that she is drawn to him because he is "kind", and as usual, that basically means he acts like a half decent human being on occasion (when he's not being an insensitive jerk who is unaware of how others feel).


That's as we all know all it takes for a physically repulsive man with stage 4 Asperger to attract the finest babes!


Not.


This lack of believable chemistry between the romantic leads hampers the show badly from beginning to end. They did dedicate one of the later episodes to some kind of flashback into the girl's life that was intended to retcon some kind of personal psychological reason for her otherwise inexplicable behavior, but it still just felt contrived. I didn't buy any of it.


So this "romcom" pretty much fails at the ROM. It also pretty much fails at the COM, because it's not particularly funny either. And the art is pretty lackluster, and the music pretty bad. It is in short a pretty shitty anime.


It is, however, not unwatchable!


The characters may be stereotypical and the plot trite, but it's still sort of *comfortable* to watch. You know what to expect right away, and then the show delivers exactly what you expected - a mediocre but mildly entertaining ride that doesn't challenge or disappoint too badly! There's something to be said for anime that simply upholds the unspoken social contract between creators and viewers in this way. I binge watched it without ever feeling like I risked getting surprised, or having to engage myself deeply in anything. Sometimes that's all you want from an anime.


I enjoyed it for what it was, and I'm going to watch season 2 next! :P

Disclaimer: I've only seen the anime, never read the source material. But honestly, after watching the anime I don't know why I'd want to.
Right out of the gate the viewer is bashed over the with generic material: We meet our protagonist: some otaku loser who everybody thinks is gross and lame, and like almost every other high school anime, he's running late for school. He gets to the shoe lockers and the only other person that was late that day was the girl with a reputation of being easy. Their punishment? clean leaves out of the pool after school. Cut to them cleaning leaves andthey get in an argument because the guy thinks the girl called him gross, which in his mind is pretty rich coming from the girl who's supposedly the school bike, when in reality she said wearing bangs over her face would make her feel gross. They argue some more and then they fall in the pool. Somehow they get it into their heads that they like each other, which in reality its just that shes the first girl who wasn't an ass to him and he's the first guy who didn't expect her to sleep with him. All in all, I've seen worst reasons to date someone, but it doesn't stop there! She then reveals that she's moving away at the end of the year!


So right off the bat, we've got our cookie cutter, bland characters established, a contrived plot to force the supposed romance to blossom, and the rest of the story sets itself up. Now, in case you're wondering, "hey, why is he describing the first episode in so much detail?", it's because this is literally the highest point in the entire show, its all down hill from here. It's just one manufactured point of drama after another, they get in arguments and make up. It's about the most generic romance anime I've ever seen.


Now, before I get into my other grievances with the show, lets talk about the art and music:


The art and animation is pretty bland, no snappy art changes to lighten the mood, no real design to the characters at all. Every character is thin and boxy, very two dimensional, which is pretty bad when you're characters are already tapped in a 2D plane to begin with. there's no beauty to the art, it's just there, it exists, and nothing more, there's just nothing to comment on because its so bland.


The music is forgettable, and that's putting it nicely. background music exists in this show, but there's nothing memorable about it. In fact, the most memorable part of the music in this anime is the OP, and that's because it drags on for what feels like an eternity, almost as if they put animation to the entire studio released song. I'm serious, this OP will put you to sleep if you let it.


Now lets talk about my continued grievances with this awful show. First, lets talk about hikari's best friend, who's a borderline furry. Guy just decides that in order to stand out more than he already does by being friends with the super otaku who has no other friends, that he's gonna start wearing cat ears every single day, so he can let his true self shine through more. 


then there's how hikari just goes full on white knight over iroha, the female lead. I gave it a pass the first time it happened, since they were "dating", but it just keeps going, as if she's just using him so other guys will leave her alone.


Hikari is somehow able to do almost anything perfectly, "when he puts his mind to it", as if thats a good enough excuse to try and make the character redeemable and not a borderline NEET whose only good quality is having never missed a day of school. He's also unhealthy obsessed with a specific magical girl anime character, to the point of watching old episodes nightly and modeling a figure of Iroha after her. 


All in all, I can't tell you enough to just not watch this at all. Looking back, it's as if some neckbeard incel thought up a situation that would make some perceived "thot" see this as a worthwhile mate and accept him as he is, while simultaneously changing her to fit his worldview, and then they decided to make an anime out of it. Which is absolutely insane. Hikari isn't even a likeable character like other hardcore antisocial and socially awkward otakus, like tomoko from watamote. She at least tried to change and better herself. Hikari thinks everyone else needs to change to accept him, and thats just not a sympathetic character trait in any show. 


DO NOT watch this unless you are some neckbearded, basement dwelling, fedora tipping, THOT shaming, white knighting, nice guy Incel, because that appears to be the target audience. Its just a bad show, and somehow this dumpster fire is getting a second season.

Ok, so first of all I'm a little bit shaken by the SCATHING reviews of this show. I'm sure this review (which is at most my second ever, but one I felt pretty compelled to write after reading the hate, especially considering I'm only giving it a 7) will be buried, but for those of you who find it, hopefully it helps.
This show (well, first cour of a 2 cour show) is not NEARLY as bad as people are making it out to be. Here are the top complaints I see: 
1. MC is basically an oblivious moron
2. MC's relationship with Igarashi is totally unrealistic,they barely knew each other!


3. Based on point 1, literally nobody would ever think the same as the MC in any of these situations, and since I can see all sides of this story MC is a dumb-dumb while I'm a romantic genius because WE ALL KNOW WHY HE'S WRONG BUT HE CAN'T SEE IT (spoiler alert, most of the time it's because we've seen the other side of the story and you can't do that in real life...dramatic irony).


This show, like many others that people pan for being high school romances (and some of them for good reason), but it's honestly one of the most realistic high school shows I've seen. If this were your *standard* high school romantic dramedy, you'd have the MC being roasted by viewers because he didn't "realize" that his crush sneaking into bed with him on the school camping trip was a sign she liked him. In this show [SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER], we have a character who doesn't realize someone likes him because he feels he'd never be liked, despite being in a relationship with someone else (who he feels he doesn't deserve to have like him). [SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER]


Quick story from my high school life, where I was a legitimately talented musician and had a strong group of friends (most of which a really eclectic mix of jocks, arts kids, drama folks, smart guys, weebs, etc...mainly because all of shared a few common interests), but had a bit of an inferiority complex in middle school where I was mostly alone - 


I was in a class with a girl named Bree (also spelled Bri or Brie, but hers had 2 e's) during freshman year, and we got along really well. I was doing my best to be outgoing and funny since I had swapped schools and basically knew nobody, and it seemed like it was going well! I had a group of friends from band (we had a solid month of practice before school, so I got to know most of them really well), and I came into the year somewhat confident. Anyways, freshman year passed, sophomore year came, and Bree and I ended up in a few of the same classes the next year. We always got along pretty well, and by a few months in had some solid inside jokes and had worked on a group project or two that I guess went alright. 


Valentines rolled around. Bree and her friend (who was always with her) were being a bit coy with me...and then her friend gave me a letter on V-day itself. As far as I remember, it only had a few hearts on it, just kind of in keeping with the day. 


I opened it up, and inside was written:


"Be mine, lol!"


"...but, will you really?" 


"xxx-xxx-xxxx"


and I NEVER CALLED HER OR EVEN TEXTED.


This girl LITERALLY ASKED ME OUT in a note, but I was too worried about it being a "joke" that I never called or texted her...and our back and forth in classes soured, and we kind of just stopped talking. 


I asked her YEARS later what she meant with that message...she said "I WAS ASKING YOU OUT YOU FUCKING ASSHOLE! JESUS YOU WERE INSECURE!!!" Luckily we just laughed after that, since she was getting married and I was dating someone, but still, it just goes to show -


HIGH SCHOOL KIDS ARE LITERALLY RETARDED AND NO LAWS OF REASON APPLY TO THEIR ACTIONS. IF YOU WERE TO SHOW AN AVERAGE HIGH SCHOOL BOY (who had never been in a "real" relationship) TAPE OF THE GIRL HE LIKED SAYING THAT SHE REALLY LIKED HIM, HE WOULD PROBABLY SAY HE WAS AT LEAST 70% DOUBTFUL THAT SHE WASN'T JUST GIVING HIM A HARD TIME.


The fact that this show gets the main characters together early on is great, because it just serves to highlight the other idiocies of high school age kids. Never trust, never doubt, but also at the same time fully trust and doubt everything while assuming your relationship will last forever. This show is the epitome of high school romance, and people don't get it because they probably never actually dated anyone in HS. 


All that being said, 7/10 for the first season - step brother at the end seemed kinda shoehorned in, and the animation was nice and watercolory, but there were a few moments where it seemed like they were just kissing with their mouths half open and not moving. Enjoyable first cour though.

If something isn't groundbreaking or revolutionary is it automatically bad?
3D Kanojo is just that, it doesn't bring that much new to the table. Stereotypical, yes... cliches, yes... bad..? Well no.
Story: Hikari Tsutsui is a step from being a NEET, he's into 2D and pretends not to see the what happens around him, his sole friend and class mate Ito who is also a otaku is the only person who he talks to. His ability to be social and interact with people ends where it begins, he's only escape from the tortures of real life are anime and manga. Until one day because he was watchinghe's favorite show he is late for school. Also late with him is Igarashi Iroha, one of the prettiest girls in school, who is a a-hole. After being ordered to clean the school pool as a punishment for being late Iroha mostly from curiosity starts to put the moves on our boy Tsutsun. But everyone in school even including him know the story's Iroha messing around with boys so he try's to the best of his ability to stay away from her. 

Stereotypical so far, it gets better. I give the story a 8 since i finished the whole anime and in retrospect some things do make more since now.


Art: ... it sucks.

The art is something that so many people complained about that iv'e almost didn't watch the show, and they are partly right. The animation leaves a lot to be desired, it's crude, it lacks depth, some time frames are just to dang long but since this is a rom-com i just didn't mind it, if it was a action or a sports anime this would have been a disaster but since it's a high school romance the animation did it's joob to help tell the story.

I'm giving it a 7 because i like the character, they are clean, nicely done and they are not "color coded". 


Sound: 

Yu Serizawa outdid her self with the role of Iroha. Coming from Mayura from Sousei no Onmyouji i can really tell the improvement and i can say that if this is the way she's headed i'm interested in what she does next.

Uenishi Teppei who did Hikari Tsutsui is a relatively new VA and this is his first big role, witch you wouldn't be able to guess just by listening to him.

The music is ok, generally no complaints about the sound

A solid 9


Characters:

This is where i come into a bit of a pickle, since i finished both seasons i would like to rate the characters on both seasons but this review is only for the first. All in all there is some character development in the show, decent enough but maybe still not quite there. Since it is a 12 episode season i can understand the lack of some big back story or getting to know character inside out but i still think it could have been a bit better. All in all the characters aren't like in some animes hard to remember, they have there motives, goals (to fall in love since it is a romcom) but all in all just little more on this front would have made this show a whole lot better.

7 on character design


Enjoyment:

Well i watched the show in one go, it was fun, it was emotional a bit. It didn't feel like i was just waiting for the episode to finish. Depends on what are you expecting, i came board without any high expectations and i really, really like really enjoyed it. I'll give it a 9 for enjoyment and almost making me late for work.


Overall:

It's one of the few shows that i didn't think about drooping. It didn't bring much new to the table and it didn't need to. It managed to tell a interesting story and for me it was fun.

Overall i give it a 8 and recommend it to all who are looking for some fun easy going romcom to watch

I would usually go through all the ratings like Story: until Overall: But i'm making this review after barely making it through episode 2 of the English Version, it's just dreadful...
From the very beginning of episode one you are BOMBARDED with trope, after trope of completely stupid anime cliches. The main character and his friend have the worse voices for their parts, the blonde guy doesn't sound anything like how he should, and the Main Character is so bland and doesn't try to do any emotion in his voice at all, and for a character whos supposed to be meek, he never sounds meek atall. On top of that i thought in the beginning the show was amping him up to be smart because he wanted a perfect attendance record that he blows twice in 2 episodes for "a convenient meeting he didn't plan on".


Before i go further with how the MC and the few people i've seen thus far are completely trope'd and don't seem to know what they are talking about half the time, let me say the writing is some of the worst shit i've seen in anime. The characters motivations change at the flip of a hat, a store owner without any proof accusers the main girl of stealing and threatens to call the police, only for the main character to come up to the store owner and proof she wasn't stealing by BLUNTLY ADMITTING HE WAS STALKING HER TO EVERYONE IN THE STORE, and SHE DIDN'T CALL THE COPS FOR THAT?!, It just cuts to the next scene... Also for even the slightest nice thing the main girl kisses the guy she doesn't know, whos been insulting her the entire time they were around one another, and everytime they get in a situation where it seems like they'll part ways the main character is just walking somewhere and BAM shes there, not on purpose but thats where she happened to be cause CLICHE PLOT CONVENIENCE. 1.This anime is a picnic anime ( shorter anime to watch between longer ones ) So first off I wouldn’t really recommend this anime for anyone that was looking for a new anime to start watching. 2. THE EPISODES: this anime is based off a manga Like most anime’s, but just don’t get too attached with it because they stopped making more episodes after episode 12 which ended in a cliff hanger. 
Hey 3.THE PLOT: ok if I have to make a summary about this anime it would be “Tsutsui and Ikarashi fought and then made up” that’s all to the plot buddy’s. So especiallymyself, personally I like watching longer anime’s like naruto and dragon ball and I usually finsh them fast because I’m so indulged in them so watching long anime’s is no problem for me. While this one was only 12 episodes I felt like my soul leaving my body every time I watched it because it was the same lame plot every episode.


 To truthfully speak this kind of plot is perfect for a manga because the reader will enjoy the long development of both characters as over time they change but that’s not true for anime because your  constantly watching the same thing, the whole entire anime there was no development it was like taking two steps back and then two steps forward and calling it progress.


 So overall I don’t think I enjoyed the anime that much but I do believe I would enjoy the manga that I would hopefully start reading soon but one thing that I did enjoy about the anime was the art, I do believe that art and animation was outstanding which is not someone common in more recent anime’s.  Other than that if your just interested in the art style of the anime could be another reason to watch it other than that I don’t think I have anymore positives but that’s my personal opinion if your still interested in watching it try watching the first 4 episodes of the anime which will technically sum up the whole anime for you since the plot is repetitive in such a small anime which made me give it a mediocre score.


 4 THE CHARACTERS: Most notably Iroha. 3D Kanojo is NOT a good show.
I have given this show a try since I wanted a show that could've realized the desires I had in watching Shigatsu wa Kimi no Uso, which was quite a disappointment for me.
3D Kanojo didn't meet my expectations, to say the least.
Now, you might be thinking, "This guy doesn't like Your Lie in April!? I won't read this sht, all his points are invalid.". Well, at least give my review a chance.
So, let's start with my disappointment for Shigatsu. Shigatsu is a GOOD show. Contradicting, yes, but hear me out. I watched it because, as everyone else usually doesstarting drama anime, I wanted to get emotional. It became a disappointment because it never even got near to making me feel anything.


A short reason would be because the main characters, which are the focus of the drama aspect of the story, did not get the development they needed. Before the "moment", the show went on for ages on sht that is completely irrelevant to the main point of the show. As I was troubled of the ongoing crap, I was force choked into feeling sad for someone that I don't even know much of (due to lack of character development). Combine these and you get a disappointing end to a good hopeful of an anime.


With all these, how do I even get to think it's a good Anime then?


Because it is!


People mistakenly equalize "Good stories" with actual "Good" shows. A good story (for you) does NOT mean that it is a good Anime, HUGE mistake.

I didn't like the show for the reasons I have dictated, but that doesn't mean it's bad.

Shigatsu has great animation, to start things off. The ost is phenomenal and iconic in the Anime community, with good reason. Seeing the Anime as a whole, you can see that a lot of passion and care is given in the creation of it and it shows! As a simple gauge, look at the OPs & EDs; they're amazing. Sadly, people think the story was good because the presentation (anime itself) was good which as I have stated, isn't the case.


With that, let's see the relationship of Shigatsu with 3D Kanojo; Why do I deem Shigatsu as a good Anime even with my dislike of it but see 3D Kanojo as the worse version (Bad anime).


*Spoilers for Shigatsu & 3D Kanojo*

You can connect the two in how they start up with the good bits of the plot. Both shows feature a heroine which "seemingly" have some kind of illness that may or may not be terminal. Both shows present the event in which the heroine doesn't have much time left. Both shows could have been good.


Now that we have the important similarities out of the way, let's now focus on the differences.


I have stated somewhere above, a summary of despite being a disappointment, why Shigatsu was good. If you remember, I have stated the care and passion given in the creation of the show as one of the reasons for it being a good show. This might be one of the most, if not the most important need of a show to be deemed respectfully pleasant.


3D Kanojo lacks ANY sign of this. Okay, compare the OP of 3D Kanojo with another of a show that aired the same season; specifically Wotakoi. Now, tell me, which of these 2 would you say lacked respect for the viewers by being awfully done to the point of torture and which was done with care and passion? You can simply take this answer with the show itself as it's basically the same throughout. For every aspect of the show, the animation was awful, the VAs sound dead inside, just like the Anime. The story was going nowhere, the characters got nothing. The show was a torture to watch and I hope no one else gets the disrespect the show has given its viewers.


tl;dr - 3D Kanojo is a massive f* you to anyone who watches it. No one says you can't enjoy watching a show like that, but facts are facts. No care was given to the show which is very evident if you actually look yourself. A lot of people "wanted" this kind of story just like they did with Shigatsu, but getting what kind of story you want does not mean it's good. Wake up, 3D Kanojo is really, really bad.

3D Kanojo is a show about the hardcore otaku Tsutsui, who only has one single (otaku) friend, and doesn't care about real girls. As you would expect, he then gets to know a girl which is not grossed out by his appearance and actually takes a liking to him. They become a couple, he starts opening up, befriends other people, and eventually someone else falls for him too, yadda yadda you know the story.
Now, the setting is of course veryshoujo-like; the very definition of an outsider starting to date a cute openminded girl. But in my opinion, it still was incredibly well done. 


What I liked:

- They start dating very early on, even in the first episode I think, and the show revolves on how they develop as a couple (and individually while being a couple)


- There is no huge love-rival drama dragged throughout a bunch of episodes, not like other shows where it seems like the whole world tries to rip a couple apart.


- Pretty much all the characters ended up to be pretty likeable to me. They have all very different personalities and each of them has their own issues to deal with, but they still get along together and it just makes an enjoyable combination.


What I didn't like:

- Sometimes Tsutsui was TOO dense in my opinion. That made it feel like the show wants to tell you that even a complete idiot can get a girlfriend. Of course, as an otaku without friends it makes sense that he can't understand much about other peoples feelings, but for me it sometimes was too much.


- I would've liked to learn more about Igarashi. Her past isn't explored that much, and you only learn from her family in the very last episode.


- Considering that from the first episode it was already known that Igarashi would have to move in half a year it had basically no impact on the show at all. Then again, that's probably the focus for the second season.

Not even sure where to begin, but to give a quick heads-up: this review will contain lots of sarcasm, just in case y'all don't get it. If you see me praising the anime, that's probably and definitely sarcasm. 
Another warning: there will be some spoilers here.
When I first saw the name and the cover art of this anime, I was genuinely interested. I was the type to not read the summaries of animes or mangas; just jumping all in to experience the ride of not knowing on what's going to happen. I had an expectation that 3D Kanojo: Real Girl was about a high schoolboy. who was some sort of gamer, somehow had his favourite character from his game come to life or some sort. But no, I was wrong, obviously. It was nowhere near my expectations. I was met with another boring story plot, but I decided to give it a chance.


Now, I regret ever giving it a chance.


One of the main reasons I strongly disliked this anime is because


1. Overly stereotypical characters.

 - The characters in this anime are extremely challenging on being able to relate to them, let alone liking them. The author does quite a terrible job in writing and creating their characters. The main protagonist, Tsutsui, was originally supposed to be an otaku who isolates himself from his classmates and happens to be bullied just because he likes anime and manga. Bonus points: he also has at least one friend who happens to have the same interests as him, if I'm not mistaken. The classmates somehow always finds a reason to pick on Tsutsui, with the author hoping that we as the audience would somehow sympathize with him and his awful life. This anime's genres were mainly romance and comedy, and they sure executed the comedy wonderfully; just not in the way it was supposed to be. The amount of exaggerated moments and actions in this anime made me laugh out of pure pity and disbelief. I wasn't sure how to react other than raising my eyebrows so high up until it reached Mars. In the real world we live in, it is true that some people may be bullied because of their interests, but for the whole school, along with some random bystanders outside the school, to dislike Tsutsui because he's an otaku or looks like one is utterly disgusting. But hey, this is the world of anime, so it should be okay, right? (Spoiler: No, not really.)


Now, on to the main protagonist's love interest, Iroha. From what I've gathered, I do believe she was supposed to be that 'one deadpan girl' who had a blunt attitude and was rumored to be some sort of whore. Not sure, I wasn't exactly paying attention to this anime from the very start. That's how uninterested I am during the 20+ minutes of the episode. But this love interest somehow meets the main character due to both being late, and apparently, she intentionally came to school late? I think she mentioned a reason why she did so, but at this point, I think I've forgotten the reason since I might've thought it was a stupid reason to arrive to school late. Iroha asks if she could date Tsutsui, but of course, he rejects. That's probably the only smartest thing he has ever done throughout the whole two episodes or less. Until he decides to stalk her to 'get to know her better', of course.


Tsutsui follows her as she goes through her day, seeing that she wasn't the 'bad guy' she was painted to be in school, I suppose. Eventually, the love interest was being accused of stealing a book by the staff. I don't work at any stores, but I'm pretty sure that the staff won't just come up to a customer and loudly accuse them of stealing, causing a huge commotion. And wow wee, the main character heroically swoops in to save the day (being the hero he is), literally stating every single thing Iroha has been doing throughout the day which marks him as a stalker. Talk about the knight in the shining armour made of gold, amirite? To my surprise, the love interest never found it creepy, nor did the bystanders said or did anything about it. Totally relatable, sister. I would 10/10 immediately marry someone who stalked me throughout the day before standing up against this accuser in a bookstore.


I will talk about their relationship more soon, but for now, let's focus on the rest of the characters. Tsutsui, being the loner he is, only has one friend, Yuuto (I had to search up his name since I don't remember 90% of the characters' names). They both have some things in common: both being otaku nerds and getting punished by their fellow classmates for liking weeb stuff. I don't really care so much about Yuuto and barely paid any attention to him (especially the anime itself), so I can't say much about him, other than "Are those real cat ears or what?"


Tsutsui also has a childhood friend who apparently bullies him a lot, saying that the only reason she does it is because she has the 'childhood friend privilege'. Nice. If only I had a childhood friend so I can totally mock and insult him 24/7 for having passions. She's just another irrelevant character I never paid attention to as well, so moving on.


His family, however, is utterly disgusting. The family is unbearably unsupportive and biased, they  actually succeeded in making me feel bad for the main character. I don't know about you, but I'd feel very awful if my sibling comes up to me and says "I don't want to be like you when I grow up because people who like a certain thing, let alone anime or manga, sucks." Also, if a family member of yours is being accused of a serious crime, are you going to tell them that they have no future and is a disgrace to the family WITHOUT even looking for evidence? Talk about some supportive family. Definitely the best, 10/10. "Oh hell, my son is a child molester although he says that he isn't and there is no proof whatsoever, so I'm just going to tell him that I won't believe in him because he literally has no life :)" < And the best mother of the year goes to Tsutsui's mom.


Moving on from the dysfunctional family, we have this blonde classmate named Takanashi who also likes Iroha. He constantly bullies Tsutsui and tries to ask Iroha out, although she is clearly dating Tsutsui. Of course, Takanashi is annoyed by the fact that Iroha chooses an otaku over the 'hot, popular blonde guy' so he is the main reason why Tsutsui is accused as a child molester after Tsutsui tries to help a little girl find her brother who happens to be Takanashi. I stopped watching after a while, but I still had a bet that Takanashi would end up being friends with Tsutsui. I heard that they did, but not in the way as I expected. I expected that it wouldn't go pretty easy, after everything Takanashi had done to Tsutsui, and falsely accusing someone could have a terrible consequence. Instead, they both hitched off as friends without a problem, which also leads me to how this anime creates conflicts and resolves them without challenging the characters and even giving them consequences.


I'm sure there are other characters that I probably missed or haven't seen yet, but merely thinking about it already gives me a migraine. On to the next reason why I despise this anime!



2. Bland and predictable story plot. Especially the overused cliches that were executed rather poorly.

 - I can't tell you how much money I've put into betting with my brother over this anime. I always predicted their cliches, saying that the bully would somehow turn into the main protagonist's friend and that a girl who also happens to be an otaku would develop a crush on the main protagonist. Most of my predictions were, 'surprisingly', correct, although I still haven't got the answer on whether Iroha is going to die or not. But seeing how this anime turned out, I think I'd like to take my 50 cents back right now. I don't think this anime would really want to kill off one of their main characters and cause a heartbreak for poor, lonely ass Tsutsui. After all, this is the anime where mistakes doesn't come with a consequence. 



3. The main protagonists' relationship isn't built on a strong foundation.

 - The main character said he wanted to date her (for some reason unknown or forgettable), and the love interest mentions that she will be leaving town in six months forever. I half expected that she was dying since she did visit a hospital, but I'm not going to buy her cheap excuse of having asthma. Eventually, she did accept, and I have two questions about it.

Why are they going out in the first place if they both knew that the love interest was going out of town forever without a single hope of coming back? Is there a reason why the main protagonist is dating her? 


And as the story 'progresses', I begin to notice the incredible lack of communication between the two lovebirds. Every time the main protagonist somehow messes up, his girlfriend won't even tell him what's wrong and expects him to figure it out himself. Damn, talk about some relationship goals, amirite? In result, this gives Tsutsui lots of self-doubt, confusion, etc. Once he resolves everything by simply apologizing, his girlfriend just forgives him that easily. So, the moral was: if you do something wrong and apologize, everything will be back to normal. :)


One of the reasons why I think that the main protagonist should not be in a relationship is because he isn't happy with himself. And if he fails to make himself happy, he won't make his significant other happy either. And I don't think his love interest did anything memorable to make him realize his flaws or change into a better person. 


I think the main reason why his love interest is dating him is because stalking her and saving her is 'so hot <3'. And if you're hoping that stalking your crush would get her/him into a relationship with you, you're wrong and you need more education asap. Even if you do get her/him into a relationship with you, I don't know what to tell you except that you both need professional help.



Conclusion:


I'd love to write more about why I despised this anime, but I think I would lose more brain cells if I kept going on, eventually. What baffles me is the fact that this anime is getting a second season. I know a lot of romantic comedy animes which had executed their stories so well and doesn't even get a second season. Again, might I remind you, this anime was featured on the Aniplex channel on television. I had high hopes for this one when I first watched the trailer way back. When I rewatched the trailer months after, I had a bad feeling about it. After watching simply 5 minutes of the anime, I was left with the question of "What in the bloody hell is happening?" and whenever I do get the answer, I sometimes wished I never asked anything, let alone watch it in the first place.


I was originally going to stop at episode two, but I decided to give it a chance and reached until the sixth episode before completely breaking down, shutting the lights and going to bed exactly at midnight. I wasted my time watching, and this anime made me appreciate 'Kotoura-san', another anime that I wasn't too fond of. A great example of romcom animes are: 'Wotaku ni Koi no Muzukashii' and 'Net-juu no Susume'. They have an amazing portrayal of realistic relationships, and instead of having to tell a cliché story about highschoolers, their main characters are working adults which is refreshing. Wotaku ni Koi no Muzukashii and 3D Kanojo: Real Girl might have some character design similarities, but the huge difference is their story-telling, character personalities, etc. 


I won't be reviewing any of the animation, voice acting, or the music in this anime. Personal thought on the OP though? I think I can relate to the singer. I would also sound lifeless inside as I sing a song for a terrible anime. Animation is sort of wonky and unpleasant to look at sometimes. I wasn't really paying attention to the voice acting since I was busy clearing off the blood in my eyes.


I will now end this rant which I call a review, and thank you for coming to my TEDx Talk. Now if you'd excuse me, I'll be going to church to repent my sins and pray to God, asking for forgiveness for watching this horrible mess.

3D Kanojo Real Girl was originally a shoujo manga that is fairly famous in Japan, I think that’s the reason why it got adapted. I never got a chance to read it’s manga, but it is on my bookmarks. I still haven’t figured out the reason why I went back and watch this, but atleast I did get to enjoy the later half of the series.
The plot was simple. An otaku guy, who’s really awkward to everyone and has only 1 friend, happens to meet a hot and beautiful girl and for some point they become a couple. That’s like every otaku’s dream romance, whichmade this series very generic as this plot is quite common but in a different setting. I think it was the progression of their story that made this series different from any other show I had seen. The problems the characters’ faced were quite realistic and relatable, which made this series really engaging and intriguing. I think that’s why the manga is quite liked by alot of people.


But the problem with this series is the inconsistent pacing and the abrupt ending of the series. There were times I feel the series was dragging the problem too much and other times, it was too fast. It was a hassle to watch cuz it made some parts of the series boring to watch. And yes, the last episode, WTF was that? It just…end. Also, introducing another character that seemed to be really important at the last episode made me have alot of questions in my mind. I know that this series will have a sequel, but bruh, at least end the season properly.


Now for the characters. I have a love-hate relationship with the lead characters. There are times I feel them and there were times I want to smack their heads and get their act together. Sigh. But the thing is, the stuff I hated about the lead characters were the stuff I liked about them. All of the characters here in this series were not just your typical 2D characters in a series, they have different sides of themselves, good and bad, that made them alot more human and relatable. Tsutsui Hikari is an awkward otaku, yes, but he is also really caring and kind to the people he cares about, and really really oblivious to his surroundings. With those traits of his, you would understand better the decisions and actions he made. Even with Igarashi Iroha, she’s a mysterious girl at the very beginning. But seeing her real and true self later in the series made me like her and understand her. I still do wanna smack their heads, but yeah, I can’t blame them.


Now, compared to the lead characters, I felt that I need more time with the supporting characters. Because the story was so focus on the lead characters, the growth of the supporting characters were either abrupt or really slow. I do hope to see them grow more in the 2nd season.


Let me say this first, I HATE THE ART AND ANIMATION. There, I said it.


I think I mentioned above that the original is a manga and I bookmarked it on my reader. The reason why I have it on my bookmarks was because of its art. I really like the artstyle of the mangaka. It wasn’t unique of anything, but it was interesting and refreshing to me. But the anime version was….BORING. I don’t like it at all. It didn’t followed the art from the manga, the animation is really bad. Everything is bad. It was really disappointing.


Okay, maybe I’m too harsh in judging the character design and all, but the animation. Uuuggghhhh,..it would have been nice if they put a bit of effort to it. It was too stiff and rigid. I think the only positive point i could give would be the sequence of the shots and scenes. That’s all.


Overall, the series was okay. It was a good watch but it was nothing amazing. I do recommend this to people who wanna watch some otaku-related romance. I’m also looking forward to its next season and the live-action movie.


That’s all for now, thanks for reading!!

When you have given up having anything to do with people, closing yourself up inside that damn thick and nothing but useless shell of yours, despite knowing yourself that it can go nowhere. Yet, for some reason, some people who doesn't know you keep coming to bother you and succeed in dragging you out of that shell. That's basically what there is to this series. 
Truthfully, this Anime was a disaster. The art was done poorly. You can tell that characters and background are not matching in both color and style for so many cuts. Then there are cuts where background felt like it wasn'tfinished in time and had to throw something in to cover it up. Over all color tried to pain it in a pink like color of romance, but actually manage to make the whole contrast with what went on with the plot even harder to overlook. Not to mention the animation was jagged. I'm not saying I want it to be smooth like some great Anime out there, but come on! You have to be kidding with that kind of animation. Sometime the action when so fast, sometime it went to slow. Cuts with repeating actions didn't quite match with sound effect either. Then, I don't know if it's just my internet, but there are even times when the audio actually cracked or jump up compared to the animation it was supposed to be with. And, best thing saved for the last, voice acting was so bad I can say with confidence that I can do a better job than what the original voice acting staff did. 


Yet, somehow, the bad acting and by that, I mean, monotonous voicing actually fits with what type the characters are, surprisingly. One is a shitty coward archetype of a normal Otaku, one is the kind of can-not-say-no bullied kid, one is I'm-so-pretty-everyone-can-only-see my-look-and-talk-about-it lonely girl. These 3 were monotonous for the most part. But what amazing is, they are supposed to be monotonous like that. Given their background as revealed in this Anime, they really should be monotonous. The 2 Otaku with being bullied by classmate, and I'm just saying, this is pretty clear since they are archetype of what went on with Otaku in Japan. The girl is told to have gone out with so many people that I bet she would be so tired of it. They are right to be monotonous. It's surprising to me what should feel like a disaster of production miss actually turned out to be just fine with how the setting for characters are "supposed" to be to fit their own archetypes. 


Yes, as I said, the characters are pretty much all but archetypes. From protagonist, heroine, protagonist best friend, romance adviser, pitiful rival, good-girl-yet-had-to-be-dumped third wheel, even mob characters are at most, archetypes of people in society. Having so many characters coming from some mold thrown into one series, it's no wonder to see that story line was at best mediocre. Shut in (by that I mean no more normal-human interaction) gets in trouble to meet a pretty girl and romance happen even if the guy was against it at first. And it was so fast for development to go from "no way" to "yeah way" in almost no time, like, 1 episode. After that, what went on was all misunderstanding except for, well, the third wheel characters. But heck, if you have experience with shoujo manga or anime, you'll see they are but old tropes and cliches. To be honest, it was painful to get through all 12 episodes. 


Indeed it was painful. But not only because of low production value or cliched plot line. But because I actually feel for well, most characters. I mean I have been most of them. Exactly because they are archetypes that they are relatable. I can see how the 2 Otaku are afraid of their desires for a romantic relationships. I can see how the heroine started to take interest in that good for nothing protagonist and how all other characters play their roles. Even if I say all of that up there about production value, I actually enjoyed it. I enjoyed how the characters felt so real, to a level of it being hilariously true that it's hurt. 


Summing it up: 

Art: 3. 

Poorly done and barely pass.


Sound: 3. 

Bad, but somehow fits where it need to. However, it doesn't change the fact it was bad.

Even the opening and ending songs were hard to listen to.


Character: 4. 

Decent;y done archetypes. But actually relatable.


Story: 5. 

Cliched. But because it's cliched, it can not go down any further.


Enjoyment: 10.

It's out of my own experience that I'm giving this disaster a 10 on enjoyment. So I don't think this is going to be of help.


Overall: 7. 

Not something I would recommend to people, but if you find it and has been in this culture long enough while having almost the same problems, I bet you would want to watch it to see how the characters reach their happy ending, even if you can see they are going to from the very beginning.

The first episodes were pretty great, because it featured social awkwardness in a more relatable and more rarely-seen way than the typical "Boy I sure do love shying away from awkward situations" way... but over time, it just turned into exactly that. 
Which is to say: give it a go, but be prepared to drop it when you stop enjoying it, because it doesn't get better. Not even for the last episode, which was just... bleh, I didn't even realise it was the end of the series at the time.
...Oh, and the other qualities? Well the art is serviceable but obviously nothing impressive and Idon't remember any of the music. But that doesn't really matter, does it?

Im wirting this review after seeing all the low scores and bad reviews. This anime is definitely worth givinga shot but i can understand why some people may hate this show.
First of all the main character. He is your typical otaku type character with no real social skills. This may annoy some people, they expect the main character to be some macho dependable hero. No, what made 3D kanojo really good for me was the fact that the main character is really realistic in that sense. Introverted socially akward people will find him super relatable. He is not your typical hero, infact most of whathe says is super cringe worthy that makes you wanna slap your face then slap him afterwards because some of you may have made the exact same mistakes with women that he makes in the anime. But i would say that all the other characters are also quite unique, well thought out and realistic. Its that realism that may put some people off, the awkward, illogical and emotional tendencies of human beings.


In terms of story its obviously not complete yet but i havent read the manga so i cant speak about how well if follows the source material.


As for art, remember this is based of a shoujo manga, if you know anything about shojo manga then you will know that the style and art is rarely ever worth getting excited about. That being said, its about the dailogue and key moments which is done relatively well. So dont watch this expecting some kyoani level animation at all. That being said the flowery background feel that you get wth screens on shojou manga is done quite well on key scenes.


I didnt particular hate or notice much of the music so while enjoyable nothing particular amazing or anything.


But overall this anime is worth watching especially if youre a kinda introverted guy, you will relate so much to this anime that if might just turn of the screen in frustration. I will definitely be looking out for a season 2 if that tells you anything about how much i enjoyed this anime.


TL DR: This anime is about the characters and their relationshp and dialouges with each other. The characters can get a little bit realistic and cringe worthy so that might put you off but that is also what makes it great. So dont be turned off by the score and give it a try. Its definitely not for everybody but some of you will definitely enjoy this anime.

I would rate this a 6 of 10. I think it had a descent beginning, but it got worse and never got better. They overdid the Otaku part of the mc. Like being socially awkward is one thing but this guy is denser than a black hole. It feels really stupid and is painful to watch after sometime.
The animation quality also has some issues. It was average at the beginning but then gets worse a various points, it gets significantly bad towards the end of the season. I loved the opening song though - never skipped it. 
The ending in itself wasn't anything great. Iguess there is going to be another season considering the introduction of a new character and some unanswered questions. Well, I cannot say I am looking forward to it. I honestly had lost interest by the 10th (?) episode itself I guess.\n\n
For those who are having second thoughts about watching this: I honestly don't feel this is worth the time and I also don't know how good the manga is either. So, if you decide to give it a try, proceed at your own risk. I think this anime deserves a try at least.

Why should you watch 3D Kanojo: Real Girl?
Story is Good (7). The story of 3D Real Girl is simple yet it is fun to watch. A full blown otaku is pulled into the world of 3D Girls (Real Life Girls) by a drop-dead gorgeous yet mysterious girl who's trying to look for something real in her world. I wanted to point out that even if my rating for the story is just 7, the amount of enjoyment I got from following the character's mundane yet interesting interactions is still a 9.
Art is Good (7). The manga, which was the source of this anime adaptation hasa very basic art that does not try to hide the feelings of its characters. As for the anime, I was looking for the same treatment/interpretation to stand out from similarly animated anime that dominates the anime market. This was a bit of a disappointment to me since I really appreciate experimentation in how anime is presented artistically. Megalo Box is one of the standouts of the 2018 Spring Anime (I will go in more detail on my review of Megalo Box after it ends almost less than two weeks from today).


Sound is Good (7). "Daiji na Koto (だいじなこと)" by Quruli the opening song is really well made. It is honest, innocent and simple that it perfectly sets the mood of the story for me. I would have given the sound an 8 or even 9 if it was the same for the rest of the OST of 3D Real Girl. I really felt that it is a wasted effort to have a good start, but a mediocre follow up. "HiDE the BLUE" by BiSH the ending song is nice but not good enough.


Characters are Good (7). Iroha Igarashi. I don't know but she immediately spring rocketed to my no. 1 favorite anime character after watching the first episode of the story. She was the reason why I kept coming back to watch each and every episode of the anime and started catching up with the manga. The air of mystery that surrounds her paired up with her unpredictable actions is a straight 1-2 punch to my heart. She truly a 10 for me; however, it is not the same for the other characters. From Tsu Tsui to Mitsuya, they were all generic characters that were not fully developed... yet. I would give an honorable mention to the character of Ayado since she is such an adorable and innocent character.


Even if the overall rating of this anime for me is good. I truly enjoyed the story which is the important thing when you watching something. You need to remind yourself sometime that watching is not a chore, but it is a tool to make feel good and be entertained. 


Just a side note, there is also a live action adaptation of this anime that would be out by September of this year. So if you are into that, please give it a shot.


With that said. I would give 3D Real Girl 7 magical Iroha figure out of 10.
